sourcesContent:
import React, { Component } from 'react' import './About.css'; export class About extends Component { render() { return (

AboutUs


Images form an important part in a web page. It not only makes the page more attractive but also more engaging for customers. Images contribute a lot to SEO. Images can help readers to better understand the article. There is a popular saying “A picture is worth a thousand words” however, it doesn’t apply to Google search, though it is certainly true when we need to spice up of thousands of dull words.

There are a lot of benefits of compressing the image in SEO. There are numerous benefits of compressing the images for performance. According to a report in November 2018, images make up on average 21% of a total webpage’s weight. So when it comes to optimizing our site, after video content, images are by far the first place you should start! It’s more important than scripts and fonts. And ironically, a good image optimization workflow is one of the easiest things to implement, yet a lot of website owners overlook this thing.

It improves the page loading speed If the page takes too long to load our visitors might get tired of waiting and move on to something else. The site will rank higher in search engine results. Large files slow down the site and search engines hate slow sites. Google is also likely to crawl and index the images faster for Google image search. Creating backups can also help it to make it faster. Smaller image file sizes use less bandwidth. Networks and browsers will appreciate small images.

) } } export default About
